docs.lead_paragraph: ANGRY about not getting a flu shot? Imagine being unable to find supplies of a medicine that limits damage from a spinal cord injury, a medicine that improves the health of a premature baby, or a medicine that fights systemic bacterial infectious. Each of these drugs, and dozens of others, are in shortage in the United States right now. On any given day, 50 to 80 drugs, many of them life-saving, may be difficult or impossible to find. Some patients die waiting for them, or because a frustrated doctor substituted another drug without having adequate training.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; In American Health Care, Drug Shortages Are Chronic

docs.snippet: Some economists say a shortage of certain drugs in the United States stems from a central feature of the nation's public health system: no one is in charge.

docs.lead_paragraph: JEF CAMPION remembers growing up here, at a time when the old Trolley Barn along the waterfront was an ominous-looking, boarded-up structure that frightened neighborhood children like himself. ''We used to dare each other to go in there,'' he said. Today Mr. Campion, a city firefighter and a wood sculptor, makes his home in the 104-year-old building, which has recently been renovated, creating loft apartments for people to work and live in. His neighbors in the building are other artists, musicians and professionals who work at home at least part of the time.
docs.abstract: Article on vacant industrial and commercial buildings in Yonkers, NY, that are being converted into loft apartments with studio space for artists, musicians and professionals who work at home at least part time; focuses on renovated Trolly Barn, three-story brick building along Hudson River waterfront; similar projects in other Westchester cities described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CAN the Kaiser Permanente model be copied? Or is it mainly a creation of its own history and culture? Talk to Kaiser physicians and they invariably speak of the cooperative spirit in Kaiser hospitals and clinics, and how they practice team medicine. ''In most other places, people want to protect their specialties and they compete for patients,'' said Dr. David Niver, a surgeon in the medical center in Walnut Creek, Calif.

headline.main: Health Care Industry Seeks a Role Model

docs.abstract: Kaiser Permanente's distinctive medical culture fostered by cooperative spirit among physicians, incentives and organization discussed; medical groups are separate from business side, so that doctors are not told what to do by accountants and do not fight with insurance companies for payments; physician performance is measured by peer reviews and patient surveys, and bonuses can add 10-20 percent to salaries, which vary by specialty, based on national scales; financial table (M)
docs.snippet: CAN the Kaiser Permanente model be copied? Or is it mainly a creation of its own history and culture?.

docs.lead_paragraph: Around the corner from a multimillion-dollar housing construction site at 105th Street and Central Park West, a couple in a subsidized apartment care for an ailing son. They are worried about how to pay an escalating electric bill. If their service is suspended, the machine pumping nutrient-rich milk into their son's stomach will stop. In Brooklyn, a woman takes custody of her teenage brother, adding to personal strains that include her grandmother's death, a divorce, and the difficulty of raising her daughter alone.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; The Hope of Charity, Reflected in 3 Working Families Who Found Help

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 93rd annual fund-raising campaign; fund offers money and other support to working poor who have had to deal with additional problems caused by poor health, domestic relations and disasters; among beneficiaries are struggling Manhattan couple caring or ailing son, Brooklyn woman taking on custody of her teenage brother and single mother in Yonkers trying to rebuild her life and provide shelter for her six children after fire destroys their home; Starr Foundation donates $1 million to Neediest Cases Fund for fifth consecutive year; photos (L)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER 18 years in private practice, Dr. Victor Silvestre was exhausted from his lonely battle, day after day, with a health care system that seemed to be working against him. A general practitioner, Dr. Silvestre found it increasingly difficult to get his patients appointments with specialists, who tended to focus on lucrative procedures instead of routine care. Paperwork and haggling with insurance companies, he said, took more and more time. ''There just had to be a better way,'' he recalled. For Dr. Silvestre, the better way was not across the border in Canada, or in some affluent nearby suburb, but in his own backyard, in Oakland. Two years ago, he joined Kaiser Permanente, the huge health maintenance organization based here. ''So many of the solutions, the ingredients of a more rational system for delivering health care, were there,'' he said.

headline.main: Is Kaiser The Future Of American Health Care?

docs.abstract: Article on Kaiser Permanente, huge California-based health maintenance organization considered leader in efforts to increase quality of care and spend health dollars more wisely; management of care and $3-billion initiative to use information technology to improve clinical care and streamline operations explained; Dr Victor Silvestre, who gave up frustrations of sole practice to join Kaiser, comments, as do Dr Francis J Crosson, director of Kaiser physicians, and chief executive George Halvorson; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Many experts and politicians believe Kaiser, an H.M.O., is doing some of the things needed to improve health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the outcome of Tuesday's presidential election too close to call, it seemed a good idea to draft advance letters of congratulation for both President Bush and Senator John Kerry. DEAR President Bush, Congratulations on your spectacular victory. You never wavered in your convictions, never cowered before critics and never let details get in the way of being ''on message.''
docs.snippet: With the outcome of Tuesday's presidential election too close to call, it seemed a good idea to draft advance letters of congratulation for both the candidates.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The flu vaccine emergency is a dramatic example of our health care crisis. In Europe, there is no shortage because governments there take responsibility for the public's health, by assuring universal health care coverage through national health insurance.

headline.main: Health Care and the Free Market

docs.lead_paragraph: I often criticize statements by President Bush, so today let me praise some of his real wisdom: Oct. 11, 2000: ''If we're an arrogant nation, [foreigners] will resent us. If we're a humble nation but strong, they'll welcome us. We've got to be humble.''
docs.snippet: I often criticize statements by President Bush, so today let me praise some of his real wisdom.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: About six years ago I went over the economic feasibility of a universal Medicare program with three distinguished economists using a system that limited the total cost of the program to 14 percent of gross national product, slightly lower than the figure for current spending.

headline.main: Health Care and the Free Market

docs.lead_paragraph: I have a confession to make. I am a drug company executive who believes we should legalize the reimportation of prescription drugs. I know that I have a different opinion from that of my employer on this matter, but to me, importation of drugs is about much more than money; it is about saving American lives. According to a study by the Kaiser Family Foundation issued in 2000, 15 percent of uninsured children went without prescription medication in the previous year because of cost, 28 percent of uninsured adults went without prescription medication because of cost, and 87 percent of uninsured people with serious health problems reported trouble obtaining needed medication. We have 67 million Americans without insurance for drugs, according to the foundation. They pay cash -- full price -- and can't always afford life-saving drugs. American drug prices are about 70 percent higher than in Canada and almost twice as high as in Europe.
docs.snippet: Americans are dying without the appropriate drugs because my industry and Congress are more concerned about protecting profits than they are about the health of Americans.
